speaker: Sam

text: And I'm Neil. In this program, we're talking about a famous leader
and teaching you some useful vocabulary. Like Chancellor, the person in the highest position in a
speaker: Sam

text: government or university, and especially the title for the head of government in some European
countries. A country such as Germany. It's a position like the pro minister in the UK.
And one of Germany's longest serving chancellors was Angela Merkel, who led the country from 2005
speaker: chancellor

text: until the recent elections in September 2021. Well, we're going to find out more about
her soon, but not before I've challenged you to answer this question, Neil.
speaker: chancellor

text: Who was Germany's first ever Chancellor? Was it A, also von Bismarck?
B, Helmut Schmidt? Or C, Franz von Pappen?
Well, my knowledge of German history isn't great, but I'll go for A, Otto von Bismarck.
That sounds quite likely. Okay, I'll reveal the answer later on.
But let's talk more about Angela Merkel now. She was an office for 16 years.
An office means in power or in charge until she stepped down last month.
Yes, that's a long time, which meant she had to make lots of decisions,
popular with some people and not with others.
speaker: Sam

text: Over that time, she's gained a nickname, Mutti, German for mother.
speaker: Sam

text: This could be seen as a compliment, but started life as more of an insult,
as BBC correspondent, Damien McGuinness, explained on the BBC radio program from our own correspondent.
The mummy Merkel image, in fact, started off as an insult from conservative rivals.
It was made up during her first term in office by hard-line conservatives in her predominantly male
party, a patronising putdown behind her back to put her in her place as a woman,
possibly even meant to be hurtful, given that in reality she has no children.
Oh dear, so the nickname of mother was really used as an insult to start with,
speaker: hardline

text: probably invented by the men in her political party, described as the hard-line conservatives,
ones with traditional and strict beliefs that can't be changed.
Yes, the nickname was used as a putdown. That's an insult used to make someone feel stupid or
embarrassed, and the intention was to make her feel less important or to put her in her place.
Well, politics is full of insults and critics, but it sounds rather cruel,
speaker: Sam

text: And Damien McGuinness does go on to say that this image is really a media myth and not quite accurate.
But the media has not always been negative about Angela Merkel. She is the longest serving amongst
current EU leaders and participated in an estimated 100 EU summits. She's often been labelled
as the only grown-up in the room, so the media has called her the queen of Europe.
What is true is that following the recent elections in Germany, her successor
speaker: Sam

text: the person who became Chancellor, will lack the experience and gravitas that Merkel has gained
over his 16 years as Chancellor. But Damien McGuinness, in his report for the BBC's
from our own correspondent programme, concludes that many people aren't sure which of her
nicknames is accurate. What word does he use to mean phrases or ideas that have become
meaningless because they've been overused? But the confusion around these cliches does point
to another truth. The Chancellor is discreet the point of sometimes being invisible,
so there's a fascination about what's really going on behind that deadpan exterior.
speaker: clichesdeadpan

text: Angela Merkel may have been in power for more than a decade and a half, but people are still not
really sure they know who she is. He used the word key shades to mean phrases or ideas that
have become meaningless because they've been overused. People are unsure which description of
her is true because she is discreet. She keeps quiet about things, so as not to attract attention.
Yes, it's hard to know what she's thinking because she looks deadpan. That means she looks
serious. She doesn't show expression or emotion. No wonder if Germany's first ever Chancellor had
a deadpan exterior. Ah, yes. Earlier you asked me who that was and I said Otto von Bismarck. Was I right?
Yes, you were. Well done. Vunderbar. Now it's time to recap some of the vocabulary we've mentioned
today starting with Chancellor, the person in the highest position in a government in some countries.
speaker: Sam

text: Hardline describes someone with traditional and strict beliefs that can’t be easily changed.
speaker: Hardline

text: A put down is an insult used to make someone feel stupid or embarrassed.
When someone is put in their place, they are made to feel less important than they are.
speaker: put in their place

text: Key shades are phrases or ideas that have become meaningless because they've been overused
and deadpan describes someone's serious facial expression that shows no emotion.
